issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description: Following YARN-8365, lookups fail from tools such as ping when using a CNAME.
fields.summary: Registry DNS lookup fails to return for CNAMEs

comments.body: Attaching a patch that fixes the issue by first adding any CNAME records that are available. This also addresses the root zone lookup issue as called out in YARN-8365 by converting the query type to NS. [~eyang] - let me know what feedback you have on the approach.

[~shanekumpf@gmail.com] Thank you for the patch.  Root SOA lookup works, and cname query works most of the time.  This patch removes a protection that we put in place, if cname record is not found after 6 recursive lookup, then we will give up on the query to avoid getting trapped in a infinite cname lookup (YARN-7731).  This patch removes that protection.  This patch also remove error conditions that may occur in the server by returning no record instead of reporting server error.  This may mask implementation problem, and it might be better to log errors and report SERVER FAILED.

Thanks for the review and feedback [~eyang]! That background on the CNAME alias handling helps. I'm not sure this is necessary given how other DNS implementations respond, but I've kept it for now until we can revisit.
{quote}This should be == right?
{quote}
That was intentional. When an A record, for example, is requested by the client, the CNAME should also be returned. We don't need to do this upstream query when a CNAME is requested because that is handled by the existing logic. However, there was no need to perform this query as part of the loop, so I've moved it out. The new patch also puts back the CNAME alias handling and error checking.

I'll note that it does look like we've got follow on work here. We should to revisit the CNAME alias handling to see if it is still needed and I'm finding MX and SOA lookups have never really worked correctly with Registry DNS which should be addressed. I'll open some issues here.

{quote}
I'll note that it does look like we've got follow on work here. We should to revisit the CNAME alias handling to see if it is still needed and I'm finding MX and SOA lookups have never really worked correctly with Registry DNS which should be addressed. I'll open some issues here.
{quote}

MX and SOA records works on the current trunk code on my cluster without this patch:

{code}
[root@eyang-1 ~]# nslookup
> server 127.0.0.1
Default server: 127.0.0.1
Address: 127.0.0.1#53
> set q=mx
> google.com
Server:		127.0.0.1
Address:	127.0.0.1#53

Non-authoritative answer:
google.com	mail exchanger = 50 alt4.aspmx.l.google.com.
google.com	mail exchanger = 30 alt2.aspmx.l.google.com.
google.com	mail exchanger = 20 alt1.aspmx.l.google.com.
google.com	mail exchanger = 40 alt3.aspmx.l.google.com.
google.com	mail exchanger = 10 aspmx.l.google.com.

Authoritative answers can be found from:
> set q=soa
> google.com
Server:		127.0.0.1
Address:	127.0.0.1#53

Non-authoritative answer:
*** Can't find google.com: No answer

Authoritative answers can be found from:
google.com
	origin = ns1.google.com
	mail addr = dns-admin.google.com
	serial = 200377020
	refresh = 900
	retry = 900
	expire = 1800
	minimum = 60
> exit
{code}

With this patch, it reports the same.  This is no different from using other DNS server.  Can you elaborate the problems that you observed?

The main goal is trying to make sure that A record lookup will produce A record, even if cname record are encountered.  Right now, the patch will report A record even if the query is looking for cname record only.  

{code}
> set q=cname
> mail.yahoo.com
Server:		127.0.0.1
Address:	127.0.0.1#53

Non-authoritative answer:
mail.yahoo.com	canonical name = fd-geoycpi-uno.gycpi.b.yahoodns.net.
Name:	fd-geoycpi-uno.gycpi.b.yahoodns.net
Address: 74.6.160.107
Name:	fd-geoycpi-uno.gycpi.b.yahoodns.net
Address: 216.115.100.123
Name:	fd-geoycpi-uno.gycpi.b.yahoodns.net
Address: 216.115.100.124
Name:	fd-geoycpi-uno.gycpi.b.yahoodns.net
Address: 74.6.160.106

Authoritative answers can be found from:
>                
{code}

The correct output should be:

{code}
> set q=cname
> mail.yahoo.com
Server:		8.8.8.8
Address:	8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
mail.yahoo.com	canonical name = fd-geoycpi-uno.gycpi.b.yahoodns.net.

Authoritative answers can be found from:
> 
{code}

The main problem is:

{code}
         if (r.getType() == Type.CNAME) {
           Name cname = ((CNAMERecord) r).getAlias();
           if (iterations < 6) {
-            remoteLookup(response, cname, Type.CNAME, iterations + 1);
+            remoteLookup(response, cname, Type.A, iterations + 1);
           }
         } 
{code}

The logic can be fixed by:

{code}
         if (r.getType() == Type.CNAME) {
           Name cname = ((CNAMERecord) r).getAlias();
           if (iterations < 6) {
-            remoteLookup(response, cname, Type.CNAME, iterations + 1);
+            remoteLookup(response, cname, type, iterations + 1);
           }
         }
{code}

Instead of looking up recursively using record type, recursive lookup based on requested type.
[~shanekumpf@gmail.com] The reordering of cname records first is unnecessary if recursive lookup uses  requested type.

[~shanekumpf@gmail.com] I saw infinite CNAME record problem before.  If first DNS server point CNAME record to a second DNS server, and second DNS server points back to first DNS server without A record.  This will cause RegistryDNS to  freeze, which we tried to fix in YARN-7731 except I made a typo on the recursive lookup for Type.CNAME instead of using request type would be more accurate.

[This stack overflow question|https://serverfault.com/questions/556854/does-the-order-of-entries-record-types-matter-in-nsd-bind-zone-config-files] provides the best answer that CNAME and A record does not matter because CNAME will be encountered first, then follow by A record resolution.
Thanks [~eyang] - attaching a new patch that passes through the user supplied query.
